text: @tladeras tidyr::expand_grid() is really useful for creating new datasets to see how fitted models perform on new data!
@tladeras @hadleywickham dplyr::anti_join() is my personal favorite.
@tladeras out of curiosity - who are the students? CS? Health Science?
@dragonflystats Biostatistics students.
@tladeras Writing your own tidy verse functions from chaining tidy verse functions using {{}} . Seriously feels like a super power sometimes
@tladeras dplyr::near is one of my favorite

@tladeras dplyr::uncount(); tidyr::complete(); tidyr::fill() / replace_na(); stringr::str_detect() / str_which(); lubridate::ymd_hms() and related functions; ggplot2::labs() - so simple, yet under appreciated!
@tladeras I don’t know if it’s less known or not, by tidyr::separate() is very useful
@AmeliaMN Yes! Very useful. I do think that {tidyr} in general is less known outside of pivot_wider() and pivot_longer().
@tladeras @AmeliaMN Forcats is also not as well known but has tons of handy functions like fct_infreq().
@tladeras Dplyr:: first and last
@tladeras I know it's not official but several times when starting out I would start collapsing things using dplyr before remembering I could just use janitor::tabyl()
@IamBugsPotter tabyl() is the best, along with clean_names().
@tladeras @IamBugsPotter i love Love LOVE Janitor
@tladeras I try to squeeze in dplyr::n_distinct() to my basic intro.  In my experience mostly useful for data checking/qaqc (i.e., becoming one with your dataset).
@aosmith16 Yes! Super helpful. I currently use skimr to give students an overview, but that's super helpful in giving single variable summaries.
@tladeras @hadleywickham Why would you want students who are just learning r to write about some obscure function?

@harlananelson @hadleywickham The point is for them to learn on their own and teach others. These aren't obscure functions, they're just lesser known ones. ; ; I can't teach them everything, so the more I can teach the meta-learning, the better they will be off in the future.
@tladeras I use forcats all the time. It's especially helpful in ggplot when reordering an axis.
@WireMonkey Definitely! {forcats} has so many useful functions.

@tladeras @hadleywickham tidyr::fill() - extremely useful when creating a usable dataset out of a spreadsheet originally built for data entry, in which redundant informations are only reported once at the beginning of the group they refer to, rather than in every row as needed for the analysis.
@tladeras tidyr::uncount(); tidyr::unnest(); dplyr::ntile()
@tladeras dplyr::coalesce() is so handy when you need it
@tladeras I personally find case_when(), select(), slice(), and separate_rows() very helpful.
@tladeras @threadreaderapp unroll

@TooSweetGeek Saluti, you can read it here: @tladeras: Hi Everyone. I'm teaching an #rstats course next quarter. One assignment is to have each student write about… https://t.co/PJH3wqv7aO Share this if you think it's interesting. 🤖

@tladeras @hadleywickham Check out the dplyr window functions, cummin, cummax, cumany and cumall. They don't seen useful at first but they can solve really tricky aggregation problems. https://t.co/aDpXqSB2Vx

@tladeras @hadleywickham %$% makes using paste() easier (among other things). ; I use %T>% View() at the end of %>% chains a lot as well.; dplyr::dense_rank() is another good one that I wouldn't have come across if I didn't know the SQL equivalent.; dplyr::group_[keys, rows, indices] are neat as well
@tladeras A lot of great ones in the thread so far! I'd also toss in `drop_na`
@tladeras pivot_wider() and pivot_longer(), formerly spread() and gather(). Incredibly useful in converting messy data into something useable

@tladeras @hadleywickham tidyr::fill() is the one that I find especially useful, for all those imported Excel files with row headings that are merged. Always assumed it existed, but didn't know its name until a colleague introduced us.

@tladeras @hadleywickham When you don't teach case_when, students will go years nesting ifelse like absolute chumps! Alternatively, to relabel discrete data I like to left_join with a crosswalk table so the associations are not hardcoded in the script.
@tladeras dplyr::lead and dplyr::lag Very practical especially within groups and yet they can be a bit tricky since it obviously raise NAs on first/last rows.
@tladeras @hadleywickham tibble::enframe()
@tladeras pivot_longer(); pivot_wider()
@tladeras @hadleywickham case_when()
@tladeras Oh man I use distinct() so much, especially with arrange() before and .keep_all = T
@tladeras tidyr:: gather () has saved me many a time when wrangling unruly data
@tladeras I haven't seen add_count but that's a good one. Also keep and discard. And string_extract
@tladeras separate" is pretty awesome and something I covet from Python
column6: so much so that I made a blog post about writing a hacky Pandas approximation! https://t.co/se5O4nR1sa"

text: @tladeras @NathanLatka - You should add this founder to your candid interview list!!
@tladeras I find myself using tidyr::unite() a lot to clean messy data - particularly useful for making unique and informative ID's for each row. coalesce() and fill() are also little known gems!  :)
@tladeras Neither of them: https://t.co/Fbw9RHE3YF
@tladeras Found myself using group_indices() several times in the past weeks. Great for giving groups sequential ids.
@tladeras tidyr::pivot_longer/wider; dplyr::n_distinct; tibble::glimpse; Are some of my most used (as well as %>% )
@tladeras nest() / unnest()
@tladeras The map() family from {purrr} was a game changer for me. as_mapper() is a nifty little function, but might be a bit advanced.
@tladeras anything from {purrr}
@tladeras case_when() is one of my favourite #rstats  dplyr functions. The formula-like syntax needs more explaining usually. This would be a good candidate for your assignment.
@vishal_katti We cover it in class. It’s way too useful to not cover it.

@tladeras One more thing that is beneficial to users would be Non Standard Evaluation(NSE); How to send columns name/ column names are strings to user functions.; ; I am yet to get my head around sym/syms ! :)
@EOTWorld28 We may get to curly-curly {{ }}, but it will probably be after we work with {purrr}.
@tladeras partial() is so useful!
@Breza pryr::partial()?

@tladeras One more and then I'll shut up 😁.  sf is not part of the tidyverse, but it might as well be.  Spatial file processing that is completely seamless with dplyr, ggplot, etc.  I make all my maps with it these days.; And finally, the tidy() function from broom.
@dh_slone Yes, {sf} is fantastic! Makes complicated spatial queries and joins much easier.
@tladeras make_valid() is the sf magic wand that solves random polygon slivers that often exist in data.
@tladeras Not tidyverse per se, but lots of these cover the 'verse:; https://t.co/lPLTvRO02z; I keep a binder of these on my desk.
@tladeras @Corey_Yanofsky I have not seen between() mentioned yet.  Are you covering magrittr?  %<>% ?

@dh_slone @Corey_Yanofsky We will cover {magrittr} - and yes between() can be very useful. ; ; I am a little leery of the assignment pipe, because it can cause mistakes due to overwriting the data frame.
@tladeras @dh_slone @Corey_Yanofsky I write essays for pay, hmu; https://t.co/T5Lv3EJd7B
@tladeras @dh_slone @Corey_Yanofsky Hello, DM me, I will assist with the task.
@tladeras @Corey_Yanofsky I've never done that and had to start over from the beginning.

@tladeras I just learnt about the function “group_walk”; My requirement was to store my groups into separate csv files and group_walk() helps in just that in just single line of code!!; ; Still face palming myself to learn this so late !!😀
@EOTWorld28 That's a nice one! Very cool.
@tladeras slice_max, slice-min
@tladeras Or n_tile!
@tladeras The readr parse_* functions. One of the listeners of #TidyX brought it up, and I've now used it so many places!!
@tladeras I think broom::add_predictions() is criminally underrated.
@tladeras complete()
@lisalendway Good one! Always forget about complete()
@lisalendway @tladeras Just used this today! So handy!
@tladeras These were less known to me for a long time, but that may just be my own fault :) so, first() last() and nth() on grouped data that is arranged.
@tladeras @allison_horst dplyr::anti_join();     dplyr::coalesce()
@tladeras Not a function, but I recently discovered you can use .before and .after with mutate() to put the new column where you want it, rather than the default all the way at the end.
@tladeras Honestly? nest() makes a lot of higher level stuff super easy
@wouldeye125 For sure. nest_by()/map() is probably one of the most powerful combos in the tidyverse.
@tladeras every(), some(), and none() from {purrr}.
@tladeras tibble::deframe(), tibble::deframe(); coercing a two-column df to named vector, which I prefer immensely to names(df) <- vec_of_names
@PeeltothePithy This one is super helpful. I didn't know  about this one.
@tladeras @PeeltothePithy Oh that’s cool! I often use purrr::reduce() for this and feel both clever and sorry for whoever reads my code next
@grrrck @tladeras There are some truly horrific reduce(left_join) statements hanging around in some old code of mine, and I apologize to my erstwhile colleagues.
@tladeras that should be names(vec) <- vec_of_names but you get it
@tladeras also enframe(); ; DAMN YOU LACK OF EDIT
@tladeras forcats::fct_reorder()! Probably quite well-known, but its contribution to ordering levels in a visually intuitive way is not to be underestimated!
@tladeras If it hasn't been mentioned already, purrr::map_dfr() or dplyr::case_when()
@tladeras crossing() is pretty handy and str_glue() can be quite powerful
@tladeras @allison_horst stringr::str_trim() is pretty good
@tladeras @allison_horst The dplyr *_join()s and, well, all of stringr! str_wrap() can be pretty useful for wrapping eg plot titles to a certain length, str_match() or str_detect() are so useful...
@ludictech @allison_horst Oh yeah, str_wrap()! I had to use this for tooltips on a plotly plot recently.
@tladeras @allison_horst readr::read_csv() & write_csv() ... (or read_delim() more generally) ?
@ludictech @allison_horst Certainly. We spend time with both {readr} and {readxl} because I think that loading data is the biggest point of frustration for students.
@tladeras @ludictech @allison_horst Ooh problems is a good function for importing rx https://t.co/P4ZR57PgOG
@apreshill @ludictech @allison_horst Ooooh. That looks great. Learning so much from this thread!
@tladeras Don't know how well known or is because it's new, but I never go a day without using across() anymore
@ArthurGailes across() is super useful!
@tladeras case_when() but that's pretty well known
@Trabendo_daze There's a reason it's well known! Super Useful.
@tladeras @allison_horst I don't think str_detect(), case_when(), and zap_label() have been mentioned yet. Highly recommend.
@JKubale @allison_horst Nice! I am a little {haven} illiterate, so happy to include this.
@tladeras slice()
@tladeras @allison_horst like unite() and separate(). have a post based on @drob's talk https://t.co/Qre4ACTRd6 #rstats
@cmdline_tips @allison_horst @drob Nice! Thanks for putting this together.
@tladeras @allison_horst @drob the post was written immediately after @drob's talk. I believe video of the talk is available now.
@tladeras @allison_horst @drob has a good talk https://t.co/s3LBiZ95tR
@robinson_es @tladeras @allison_horst @drob And @robinson_es herself has the lesser known stars talk https://t.co/80zdiWhIn4
@robinson_es @tladeras @allison_horst @drob One of the favorite. Also his screencast are the best. So much things to learn from it
@robinson_es @allison_horst @drob Noice! Thanks, Emily.
@tladeras mutate_at() and mutate_if() 😍
@tladeras There are plenty of lesser known experimental functions in dplyr 1.0.0 like with_groups(). Also some experimental features like .keep in mutate()
@tladeras purrr (and furrr) in general imo! I don't know that map_* is more complicated than loops, but I think they're underutilized. Also tidyr::nest and forcats::fct_reorder
@MikeMahoney218 We will get to {purrr} eventually. I've been trying to slowly distentangle the use case so one concept is learned at a time. It's been tricky. ; ; https://t.co/A6r9jWtsCV

@tladeras TIL about `safely` 😂 I've mostly been writing package code recently & am reluctant to include tidyverse dependencies, but boy oh boy do I have some horrifying `tryCatch` calls that could probably stand to be replaced...
@MikeMahoney218 Ha. safely()/possibly() can be super useful and I just learned about it by putting this section together...
@tladeras I went for way too long not knowing about purrr::pluck()
@tladeras Oh oh and case_when() lets me be super lazy.
@tladeras @allison_horst Forcats::fct_relevel() and forcats::fct_reorder()
@tladeras Hoist() - when you’re dealing with JSON (or dynamodb in my case) it’s a lifesaver.
@tladeras if_else (and an example of where you need to use it/where baseR ifelse breaks down)
@chrishanretty Super useful!
@tladeras @allison_horst anti_join()
@tladeras mutate(across()) as in; ; data.frame(a=c(q"
@JJVenky Yup, mutate(across()) is great. I do cover {tidyselect} in my {tidyowl} tutorials: https://t.co/pRvC9YJZQG
@tladeras @allison_horst dplyr::coalesce()
@tladeras dplyr::pull(), to emphasize the difference between a vector and a one-column dataframe.
@_echong This is really one of the hardest concepts to teach, but agreed, pull() makes it much more clear.
@tladeras I think all of the scales package is helpful; ; https://t.co/s5WMZcWwYR; ; I especially like breaks_pretty and the label functions: https://t.co/PtrVT2R7dM
@apreshill For sure. I usually don't get to scales when I teach {ggplot2}, but I think it might be worth highlighting the useful cases like breaks_pretty().
@tladeras Oh and one more! Sometimes dplyr::group_indices is helpful. The actual reference page is less helpful, but this discussion on the implementation is quite good: https://t.co/sD3iauuN9B
@tladeras I am frequently surprised by how few people know about lag()
@gvwilson @tladeras lead() and lag() are awesome for working with transect point data.
@gvwilson Agreed. The documentation/examples are a little terse for lead()/lag(), which may be why few people use them.
@tladeras @gvwilson I think in general the window functions could use some love https://t.co/8z9DdvFQgt
@apreshill @gvwilson Agreed! I think the window functions are really useful.
@tladeras left_join() and other joins, separate(), recode(), pivot_longer(), pivot_wider(), filter()
@kaiz_p All very useful! I sometimes do get confused over whether to teach recodeI() vs case_when() - they're both useful, but the use cases are different.
@tladeras Good point! ; I previously used case_when() for all my recoding needs, but then I discovered recode() and it’s so much easier. Less code = fewer mistakes!
@tladeras I now use case_when() mostly when I’m looking for a string -- grepl() or when working across multiple columns -- case_when(A == “a” & B == “b” ~ “ab”)
@kaiz_p @tladeras (TRUE ~ You missed one")"
@EvenKeely @kaiz_p I feel seen.
@kaiz_p Very true. It can be hard to see which cases" you missed when you write a case_when() statement
column6: much like writing nested if() statements."

text: @tladeras dplyr::arrange & helper dplyr::desc; dplyr::coalesce; tidyr::replace_na; ; https://t.co/h9ew04PYcU
@Corey_Yanofsky Ha! ; ; And coalesce()/replace_na() are great. Adding them to the list.
@tladeras @rstats4ds do you teach tidyverse directly or base r first?

@Recon1974 @rstats4ds I teach just enough base R for them to understand vectors, functions, and data.frames. ; ; You can see the previous class here: https://t.co/4WweuqMSl8; ; The rest is mostly tidyverse, except for the cases when they will encounter base-R a lot.

@Recon1974 @rstats4ds I know this is probably controversial, but my goal is to get them up and working usefully as quickly as possible, rather than teach a standard programming course, which you have to learn a lot of things before you do something useful.
@tladeras lubridate::floor_date; ; I have recently become a HUGE fan!
@BeltzEcology @tladeras Shout out to tsibble; if you’re using times series data you should def check it out
@BeltzEcology @tladeras also lubridate::parse_date_time() is kinda magic
@JenRichmondPhD @BeltzEcology It is *definitely* magic.

@tladeras @JenRichmondPhD @BeltzEcology most of lubridate is magical.  I use the heck out of ymd...() and similar, with_tz() and force_tz() take care of my biggest headaches, floor_date(), and ceiling_date(), etc.
@BeltzEcology Ooh, this is great! Thanks!
@tladeras Welcome!
@tladeras I use these all the time:; tidyr::uncount(); tidyr::separate and tidyr::separate_rows(); forcats::fct_inorder(); forcats::fct_infreq()
@emilmalta @tladeras Been using forcats::fct_explicit_na() of late.
@emilmalta Yes, we cover tidyr a little bit. These are great suggestions, especially separate_rows()
@tladeras @emilmalta Yes! Separate_rows is my life - so useful!!

@tladeras One thing that really made everything click for me, when learning tidy data, was that uncount() is in tidyr, and not dplyr.; ; It’s kinda subtle, but it was the thing that made me realize that tidying!=transforming.
@emilmalta Yes, this distinction escaped me at first. I guess it's like the form versus content distinction.
@tladeras @rstatstweet pivot_longer() and pivot_wider() are great!
@kaija_bean @rstatstweet They are great!

@tladeras @rstatstweet And although they're basically inverses of each other, each one had different arguments and different things to pay attention to, so I could easily see one student doing each of them without too much overlap.
@tladeras A few that come to mind: dplyr::case_when(), purrr::map(), dplyr::group_map(), purrr::walk(), and purrr::pluck().
@JayUlfelder Yup, these are really useful! I do cover case_when() because it's so universally useful. ; ; And I'm going to cover {purrr} a little bit. group_map() and walk() are great suggestions.
@tladeras Is tidyr::fill() lesser known? [regardless I love it]; ; Sharing just in case you haven't seen this! https://t.co/cpJfD56rxB
@ivelasq3 Ooh! This is perfect. Thanks!
@tladeras ggplot2::cut_width, cut_number and cut_interval to transform continuous variables into discrete bins
@francisco_yira Ah, very interesting!
Here's the list so far:; ; - dplyr::relocate(); - dplyr::count() / n(); - dplyr::distinct(); - dplyr::glimpse(); - dplyr::slice(); - ggplot2::geom_count()
@tladeras dplyr::add_count() is often useful
@tladeras ggplot2::stat_summary is fun; ; I use a lot of the stringr functions, str_remove(), str_detect(); ; pivot_longer() and pivot_wider() are fairly simple to grok and are incredibly useful
@delaBJL @tladeras str_wrap is also a fantastic one
@tladeras case_when(), group_by()/summarise()
